topic.title: Provisioning and De-provisioning

section.title: Ethernet Client Datapath Segments
section.p: There are three datapath segment provisioning options when configuring the Ethernet Subsystem for an Ethernet Rate.

li.p: Ethernet clients are terminated and their packet payloads are sent to the Interlaken interface.
Ethernet clients are terminated and their packet payloads are OTN mapped or the Ethernet client is OTN mapped transparently.
Ethernet clients are passed through the device transparently in re-timer mode.

section.p: The API g5_api_enet_prov() is used to configure the options above and their datapath segments are shown in the following figures.

Figure 1 shows the datapath configured from the SERDES interface(A) through the ENET Subsystem to the edge of the ENET block(B) for Ethernet clients that are terminated to the Interlaken interface via the DCPB or Ethernet clients that are OTN mapped and pass through the ECPB to the MAPOTN block.

fig.title: Ethernet Datapath Segment Provisioning: Packet Termination or OTN Mapping

section.p: Figure 2 shows the datapath configured from the SERDES interface(A) back through the DSIS block(B) for Ethernet clients that transparently re-timed from SERDES Bank A to SERDES Bank B.

section.title: Ethernet Client Provisioning API Details
section.p: The g5_api_enet_prov() API provisions an Ethernet client datapath across the ENET Subsystem from the SERDES up to the DCPB or ECPB Subsystem. This function is used to provision a regular ENET client in xGE rate (x = 10, 25, 50, 100, 200, or 400) or FlexE Unaware 100G BASE-R members. This function is also used to provision a SERDES port only up to the DSIS configuration in the retimer application. After this function is called, the datapath is provisioned with Tx path generating IDLE and Rx PMON available for monitoring the packets. The ENET client channel is provisioned but not activated at the DCPB or ECPB subsystem after this function is successfully executed. Note that a retimer datapath does not allocate any ENET related resources and does not provide PMON based capabilities. There are no IDLEs generated as the retimer application is a SERDES-DSIS data path only. The g5_api_enet_prov() API has the following parameters and associated enumerated types.
The device_id parameter is the device instance. The chnl_id parameter is the user defined ENET channel. The serdes_port_id parameter is the SERDES port ID for this ENET channel.
The SERDES port selection options are provided by the pin_mode parameter from the enumeration g5_serdes_pin_mode_t shown in Table 1 below.

entry.p: SERDES Port operates for up to 28G pin rate.

SERDES Port operates for up to 56G pin rate, multi-pin ports use adjacent lanes to form the port Adjacent lanes are 0, 1 or 2, 3 for 100G port applications, or 0,1,2,3 for 200G port applications, or 0, 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 for 400G port applications

section.p: For all the Ethernet modes above the mode parameter of the g5_api_enet_prov() API selects the Ethernet rate via the g5_enet_port_mode_t enumeration. Table 2 shows the enumerator values below.

entry.p: 100GE port to allow FlexE Demux passive monitoring in FlexE unaware mode

section.p: The serdes_port_only parameter of the g5_api_enet_prov() API selects retimer mode. When set to TRUE no ENET resource is provisioned, only the DSIS resources are provisioned.

The last parameter of the g5_api_enet_prov() API is the fec_type that uses the enumeration g5_enet_fec_mode_t to configure 25G and 100G NRZ pin type. PAM4 pin type always requires KP4 FEC and doesn't need to be specified. The enumerator choices are as follows:

li.p: No FEC as selected by the enumerator G5_ENET_FEC_MODE_NONE where FEC mode is disabled and no processing is done.
Reed Solomon KR4 (528, 514) FEC correction as selected by the enumerator G5_ENET_FEC_REED_SOLOMON_KR4 where KR4 FEC mode is enabled.

section.p: The device supports the following combinations of FEC, pin_mode, and * rates.

table.title: FEC, pin_mode and rate Options for the g5_api_enet_prov() API

section.title: FlexE Interface Group and Client Datapath Segment Provisioning
section.p: There are three FlexE operational modes supported by the device: FlexE PHY Terminated, FlexE OTN Aware/Unaware, and FlexE PHY Aware. Each mode has a unique provisioning procedure for FlexE interface groups and client datapath segments detailed in the following sub sections.

In FlexE PHY Terminated mode, FlexE clients from FlexE groups on physical 100GE ports are terminated to the Interlaken PIF interface or are mapped into OTN payloads. The provisioning sequence and APIs are shown below.

li.p: FlexE groups on physical 100GE ports have their configuration options defined with the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API.
N x FlexE 100GE PHYs are added to the group with the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API. N = 1 to 6.

Provisioning and activation of the FlexE group defined with steps 1 to 2 above is done with the g5_api_flexe_group_config() API. An error code will be returned if the API in steps 1 to 2 were not called in an atomic sequence or if insufficient PHY and (sub)group configuration information has been supplied.

FlexE clients inside the groups are provisioned with the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API. FlexE clients are either terminated to the DCPB to be sent to the Interlaken PIF interface or are mapped to ODUk payloads via the ECPB.
The g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API must be called to update the FlexE group calendar as the final step.

section.p: For full details on the parameters of the APIs above see the Provisioning and De-provisioning section of the ENET Subsystem.

FlexE group configuration, PHY add(s), group provisioning and group activation is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Group_Segment_Provision_Serdes_Int_2je6588x9 below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the SERDES interface(A) through the FlexE block(B) in the ENET subsystem.

fig.title: FlexE Group Segment Provision: FlexE PHY/Group

section.p: FlexE client provisioning for clients that will be terminated to the Interlaken PIF interface is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_Flex_3je6588x9 below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the FlexE Mux block (A) to the DCPB block(B).

fig.title: FlexE Client Datapath Segment Provisioning: Interlaken Packet Termination Traffic

section.p: FlexE client provisioning for clients that will be mapped to ODUks is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_Flex_4je6588x9 below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the FlexE Mux block(A) through the ECPB block through the MAPOTN to the OCPB block(B).

fig.title: FlexE Client Datapath Segment Provisioning: OTN Mapped Traffic

section.p: In FlexE OTN Aware/Unaware mode, FlexE clients from FlexE groups from ODUCn payloads are terminated to the Interlaken PIF. The provisioning sequence and APIs are shown below.

li.p: FlexE group configuration options are defined with the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API.
N x FlexE 100GE PHYs are added to the group with the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API. N = 1 to 6. These PHYS are virtual as they are not associated to physical 100GE ports, rather to ODUCn payloads.
M x FlexE sub groups are added with the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add(). M = 1 to 6 and M <= N.

Provisioning and activation of the FlexE group defined with steps 1 to 3 above is done with the g5_api_flexe_group_config() API. An error code will be returned if the API in steps 1 to 3 were not called in an atomic sequence or if insufficient PHY and (sub)group configuration information has been supplied.
FlexE clients are provisioned with the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API. FlexE clients are terminated to the DCPB to be sent to the Interlaken PIF interface or are mapped to ODUk payloads via the ECPB.
The g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API must be called to update the FlexE group calendar as the final step.

section.p: For full details on the parameters of the APIs above see the Provisioning and De-provisioning section of the ENET Subsystem.

FlexE group configuration, PHY add(s), sub group add(s), group provisioning and group activation is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Group_Segment_Provision_OTUCn_Mapp_aje7i3ktq below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the OCPB block(A) to the FlexE block(B) in the ENET subsystem.

fig.title: FlexE Group Segment Provision: FlexE OTN Mapping

section.p: FlexE client provisioning is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Client_Datapath_Segment_Provisioni_bje7i3ktq below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the FlexE Mux block (A) to the DCPB block(B).

fig.title: FlexE Client Datapath Segment Provisioning: Interlaken Packet Termination Traffic

section.p: In FlexE PHY Aware mode, FlexE groups and subgroups from physical 100GE ports are transparently mapped to ODUk and ODUCn payloads. The provisioning sequence and APIs are shown below.

li.p: FlexE group configuration options are defined with the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API.
N x FlexE 100GE PHYs are added to the group with the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API. N = 1 to 6.
M x FlexE sub groups are added with the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add(). M = 1 to 6 and M <= N.

Provisioning and activation of the FlexE group defined with steps 1 to 3 above is done with the g5_api_flexe_group_config() API. An error code will be returned if the API in steps 1 to 3 were not called in an atomic sequence or if insufficient PHY and (sub)group configuration information has been supplied.

section.p: For full details on the parameters of the APIs above see the Provisioning and De-provisioning section of the ENET Subsystem.

The FlexE group provision is shown in #Datapath_Segment_Provisioning_APIs_and_t_giuu0en0v/fig_FlexE_Group_Segment_Provision_Serdes_Int_cje7i3ktq below. In this case the datapath is provisioned from the SERDES interface(A) to the FlexE block(B) in the ENET subsystem. Mapping of the FlexE Aware group is done with the g5_api_client_map_cfg() API and described below.

fig.title: FlexE Group Segment Provision: Serdes Interface to FlexE Block

section.title: FlexE Group, Subgroup and Client Provisioning API Details
section.p: The g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API initiates collection of a FlexE group's configuration. It has the following parameters and associated enumerated types:

The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API is the device instance.The chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API is a user specified channel ID for FlexE Group. This is not the same as the 20-bit FlexE Group number that used to specify the "FlexE Group Number" in the FlexE overhead as there is no guarantee that the FlexE Group numbers will be unique in the network. This is a unique channel ID used to identify a FlexE group on each device.
The mode parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API chooses the FlexE mode via the g5_flexe_mode_t enumeration shown in Table 4 below.

entry.p: A FlexE Group with each FlexE PHY connected to a 100GE physical port. FlexE clients may be terminated to ILKN PKT interface or ODUk/ODUFlex transported through mapper path.

A FlexE Group with the set of FlexE PHY transported over one or more ODUFlex (sub)groups using G.709 17.12 mapping procedure. FlexE Clients within the FlexE Group may be terminated to ILKN PKT interface.
A FlexE Group with each FlexE PHY transported over OTN using ODU4 GMP mapping. FlexE Client within the FlexE Group may be terminated to ILKN PKT interface.

A FlexE Group with each FlexE PHY connected to a 100GE physical port. The FlexE PHY making up the FlexE group are assigned to one or more (sub)groups and the subgroups are transparently transported over OTN using G.709 17.12 mapping procedure. There is no access to FlexE Clients in this operating mode.

section.p: The flexe_group_number_tx and flexe_group_number_rx parameters of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API are a 20 bit field that chooses the FlexE group number that mapped to the 'FlexE Group Number' overhead field in Block #1 bit 12-31 of FlexE overhead.
The last parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API is the enumeration g5_flexe_calendar_mode_t. FlexE calendar modes are shown in Table 5 below.

entry.p: FlexE_MUX acts as a 'master' by initiating the calendar configuration. The calendar configurations are transmitted from the FlexE_MUX to the FlexE_DEMUX where FlexE_DEMUX acts as a 'slave' of the far end FlexE_MUX. FlexE_DEMUX calendar locations are not known until the far end FlexE_MUX advertises them. If the timer expires upon switching the calendars, force the switch and continue.

FlexE_MUX acts as a 'master' by initiating the calendar configuration. The calendar configurations are transmitted from the FlexE_MUX to the FlexE_DEMUX where FlexE_DEMUX acts as a 'slave' of the far end FlexE_MUX. FlexE_DEMUX calendar locations are not known until the far end FlexE_MUX advertises them. If the timer expires upon switching the calendars, return an alarm to the application layer, do not perform the switch and await for the application layer to proceed with next steps.
A and B calendar configurations are fixed and always uses the A calendar configuration as the calendar configuration in use.

A network management system owns the Near End and Far End FlexE_MUX and FlexE_DEMUX nodes. The network management system configures the FlexE_MUX and FlexE_DEMUX calendars directly and controls both ends when to switch calendars.

section.p: The g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API adds a single FlexE PHY into a FlexE Group. A FlexE Group can have maximum 6 PHYs. To add more than one PHY in a FlexE Group, this function needs to be called multiple times. When the FlexE Group is provisioned all calendar slots of a PHY will report unused or unavailable. Note the PHYs are to be added in the logical PHY order within the group. The g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API has the following parameters and associated enumerated types:
The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is the device instance.The chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API the channel ID for this FlexE PHY.

The serdes_port_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is the SERDES port ID for the FlexE PHY. If there is no physical SERDES interface, serdes_port_id is set to the reserved value, G5_FLEXE_SERDES_UNUSED. This reserved value is used for G5_FLEXE_MODE_OTN_AWARE(FlexE Terminated Aware) and G5_FLEXE_MODE_OTN_UNAWARE modes.
The group_chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is the channel ID assigned to the FlexE Group this PHY is being added to.

The flexe_phy_number_tx parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is an 8 bit PHY number that is expected in the 'PHY Number' overhead field in Block #2 bits 9-16 of the FlexE overhead. For transmit path, this number is used to set corresponding bits in the 'PHY Map' overhead field in Block #2 bit 1-8 of the FlexE overhead. The OH PHY number valid range 1-254.

The num_unavailable_slots_tx and num_unavailable_slots_rx parameters of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API are the number of unavailable calendar slots within the PHY. If the FlexE group is carrying a FlexE client to MAPOTN using G.709 17.12 Aware mapping, the number of unavailable slots can be asymmetric in transmit and receive direction on a particular PHY. The total number of unavailable slots in a FlexE group must be the same in both transmit and receive directions as MAPOTN does not support asymmetric uni-directional bandwidth configuration. Configured with multiples of 5 (0, 5, 10, or 15).

The flexe_phy_number_rx parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is an 8 bit PHY number that is expected in the 'PHY Number' overhead field in Block #2 bits 9-16 of FlexE overhead. For Rx, this number is used to check for match against the transmit PHY number from the Far End FlexE Mux.

The SERDES port selection options are provided by the enumeration g5_serdes_pin_mode_t of the pin_mode parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API. The enumerator G5_SERDES_PIN_MODE_NRZ configures the SERDES port for rates up to 28 Gbps. The enumerator G5_SERDES_PIN_MODE_PAM4_ADJ configures the SERDES port for 56 Gbps.
The last parameter of the g5_api_flexe_phy_add() API is fec that uses the enumeration g5_enet_fec_mode_t. The mode choices are as follows:

li.p: No FEC as selected by the enumerator G5_ENET_FEC_MODE_NONE where FEC mode is disabled and no processing is done.
Reed Solomon KR4 (528, 514) FEC correction as selected by the enumerator G5_ENET_FEC_REED_SOLOMON_KR4 where KR4 FEC mode is enabled.

section.p: The g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API assigns one or more FlexE PHY for a FlexE Group to a (sub)group. A FlexE group can be broken down into m (m = 1-6) (sub)groups where m must be less than or equal to the number of PHYs. To break a FlexE group into multiple (sub)groups, this API needs to be called multiple times. Similar to a FlexE group, a (sub)group can have n(1-6) PHYs. For example: a FlexE group having 6 PHYs needs to break into two (sub)groups, with 2 PHYs in one (sub)group and 4 PHYs in another. In this case this API needs to call twice and each time the PHY Ids belonging to the (sub)group needs to be listed in phys_chnl_id_X parameter. This function is mandatory for G5_FLEXE_MODE_OTN_AWARE mode and G5_FLEXE_MODE_PHY_AWARE modes and not applicable for any other modes of operation.The g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API has the following parameters:

The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API is the device instance.The chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API is a user specified channel ID for FlexE (sub)Group. The group_chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API is the channel ID for FlexE Group this is a sub group of.

The phy_chnl_id_X, where X = 0 to 5, parameters of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API are PHY IDs assigned to the FlexE (sub)Group. This is the logical order of PHYs in the (sub)group. If phy_chnl_id_X = G5_MAX_UINT32, then PHY X is not is assigned to the FlexE (sub)Group
The g5_api_flexe_group_config() API provisions and activates a bi-directional FlexE group. It has the following parameters:

The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_config() API is the device instance.The chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_config() API is a user specified channel ID for FlexE Group and matches the channel used in the associated FlexE Group's g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API call.

The g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API used to provision a FlexE client to a FlexE group. This API associates the FlexE client to the FlexE group's calendar slots. This API can be used in an additive manner to provision Tx channel only or Rx channel only or both. The g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API has the following parameters and associated enumerated types :

The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API is the device instance.The chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API is a user specified channel ID for FlexE (sub)Group. The group_chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_subgroup_add() API is the channel ID for FlexE Group this is a sub group of.

The oduk_mapping_mode parameter of of the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API is defined by the enumeration g5_oduk_mapping_mode_t. This parameter specifies the mapping mode for FlexE clients being transported over ODUk/ODUFlex and is not relevant and ignored for FlexE client being transported to the Interlaken packet interface. The enumerators are shown in Table 6 below.

entry.p: No ODUk mapping. This client is terminated to an Interlaken packet channel. The chnl_id for the Interlaken packet channel must be reused.
This is for a 64b/66b stream with all idles and alignment markers removed. The MAPOTN block uses G.709 17.11 IMP mapping to map the FlexE client to the ODUflex.
Only valid for 10GE mode, GFP packets mapped via Gsup43 Clause 6.2 into C49 serial stream padded with idles. MAPOTN uses G.7041 7.9 (GFP mapping) mapping of FlexE client to the ODU2.

This is for an Ethernet CBR stream with alignment markers. The MAPOTN block uses the OIF 7.2.2 mapping of FlexE client to the ODUflex. Depending on the FlexE client rate, the MAPOTN uses either BMP or GMP mapping. 2x 5G slots defines an ODU2e container size.
2x 5G slots defines an ODU1e container size.

section.p: The tx_client_data.flexe_client_number and rx_client_data.flexe_client_number parameters of of the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API are 16 bit unique FlexE client numbers that are inserted to the 'Client calendar A' or 'Client calendar B' overhead field in Block #3 bit 1-16 or bit 17-32 of the FlexE overhead. Valid values for tx_flexe_client_number and rx_flexe_client_number are 0x1 - 0xFFFE. If provisioning only the Tx client, the rx_flex_client_number can be set to 0, and vice versa.

The FlexE client may be added to multiple bonded Ethernet PHYS within a group by specifying slots in more than one PHY by using the phy_tx_client_slots_X and phy_rx_client_slots_X, where X = 1 to 6, parameters of the g5_api_flexe_client_prov() API. These are a set of calendar slot locations across 6 logical PHYs to describe the calendar slots used by the FlexE client in each of the PHYs in the FlexE group. The number X of client_slots_X is the logical PHY number of the 100G port in the FlexE group. If provisioning the Tx client only, the phy_rx_client_slots_X can be set to 0, and vice versa. The PHY element order must match the PHY element order defined in g5_api_flexe_phy_add(). For example, if a FlexE client is using 2 calendar slots in logical PHY 0 and 10 calendar slots in logical PHY 1 to carry 60G data, this can be shown as rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[0] = 0x3; rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[1] = 0x3FF; rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[2] = 0; rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[3] = 0; rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[4] = 0; rx_client_data.flexe_client_slots[5] = 0. When the FlexE group's calendar update mode is set to G5_FLEXE_CALENDAR_SLAVE_FORCE_MODE or G5_FLEXE_CALENDAR_SLAVE_ALARM_MODE in the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API, the FlexE_DEMUX will inherit the calendar slots from the Far End FlexE_MUX. At minimum, 'flexe_client_number' must be specified when provisioning the Rx FlexE client when the FlexE group's calendar update mode is either of the two SLAVE modes. When 'flexe_client_number' is provided, 'flexe_client_slots' of rx_client_data can be left as {0, 0, 0, 0, 0 ,0}. The g5_api_flexe_client_slots_get() API can be called to retrieve the received calendar slots advertised from the Far End FlexE_MUX.

The g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API is used to switch the calendars for the FlexE Group to add/remove FlexE clients. It can work independently on either the MUX, DEMUX, or both. Note that the calendar update mode is selected by the calendar_update_mode parameter of the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API. SeeTable 5 above. The g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API has the following parameters and associated enumerated types.

The device_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API is the device instance.The group_chnl_id parameter of the g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API is a unique identifier for the FlexE group. This was the number specified in the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API.

The cal_update_scope parameter is specified by the g5_flexe_calendar_update_mode_t enumeration for the g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API and is the scope of calendar switch operation on the MUX, DEMUX, or both. The enumerators are shown inTable 7 below.

entry.p: Update occurs on the MUX only.
Update occurs on the DEMUX only.
Update occurs on MUX and DEMUX.

section.p: The ms_timer parameter of the g5_api_flexe_calendar_update() API is a timer for the MUX after changing the outgoing CR bit to the DEMUX. The recommended timeouts are a minimum of 15ms which is 3 complete transmissions of the calendar to the DEMUX. Upon a timeout, the action taken will be specified by calendar_update_mode in the g5_api_flexe_group_prov() API. This parameter is unused if calendar_update_mode is either STATIC mode, or NETWORK mode.

section.title: Ethernet and FlexE Client De-Provisioning
section.p: The g5_api_deprov() API is used to de-provision Ethernet Port, FlexE Group and FlexE Client datapath segments. The parameters and associated enumerated types are below.
The device_id parameter is the device instance. The chnl_id parameter of the API is the channel ID for the Ethernet Client, FlexE Group or FlexE Client to be de-provisioned.

The enumerated type g5_deprov_t of the g5_api_deprov() API defines the scope of resources that are cleaned up as part of a de-provisioning operation when a partial or completely configured datapath is torn down. The enumerator G5_DEPROV_SEGMENT is used when de-provisioning Ethernet clients and FlexE groups associated chnl_id and any children of chnl_id following disconnection at OCPB or DCPB switch. Children of chnl_id are the FlexE Clients of a FlexE Group. The enumerator G5_DEPROV_PATH_FULL is used when de-provisioning chnl_id and any children of chnl_id including the de-provisioning of a connected chnl_id until those connected chnl_id are completely removed.

section.title: Example Code
section.p: The following example code can be used to provision a 100GE port.
The following example code demonstrate how to provision a FlexE group on the 6x100G Serdes ports.
The following code demonstrate how to provision a 50G FlexE client which uses 10 calendar slots of logical PHY 0.
The following example code can be used to de-provision an ENET port.
